defs.etymology: The Icelandic pronoun continues Old Norse ek, from Proto-Germanic *ek, from Proto-Indo-European *éǵh₂. The pronoun is attested, in Proto-Norse inscriptions, since at least the 3rd century.

examples: Og Guð sagði: sjá, eg gef ykkur alls konar sáðberandi jurtir  […] Then God said, “I give you every seed-bearing plant  […] ”
Then God said, “I give you every seed-bearing plant  […] ”
Upp, upp, mín sál og allt mitt geð,
upp mitt hjarta og rómur með,
hugur og tunga hjálpi til.

herrans pínu ég minnast vil.
translation by William Charles Green:
Up, up, my soul and all my mind,Up, O my heart and voice combined;Help, thought and tongue; for I would fainWake memory of our Lord's dear pain.translation published in Parergon, issues 1–13 , page 31:
Up, up my soul and all my mind,up my heart and voice as well.Thought and tongue help out.I intend to remember the Lord's suffering.

up my heart and voice as well.

Kvíði ég ei dauða,
konulaus maður,
— Þekki ég þig? sagði hann. Um hvað ertu að tala? Hver ertu?

— Ég heiti Erlendur. Ég er að rannsaka morð á manni að nafni Holberg í Reykjavík.
Jar City: A Reykjavík Thriller, translation by Bernard Scudder:
"Do I know you?" he said. "What are you talking about? Who are you?""My name’s [=I am called] Erlendur. I’m investigating the murder of a man from Reykjavik by the name of Holberg."

Jar City: A Reykjavík Thriller, translation by Bernard Scudder:
"Do I know you?" he said. "What are you talking about? Who are you?""My name’s [=I am called] Erlendur. I’m investigating the murder of a man from Reykjavik by the name of Holberg."
"Do I know you?" he said. "What are you talking about? Who are you?"
"My name’s [=I am called] Erlendur. I’m investigating the murder of a man from Reykjavik by the name of Holberg."

text: first-person singular indicative present of vera
third-person singular indicative present of vera
examples: Ég er skemmtilegur.I am fun
I am fun
Hver er ég?Who am I?
Who am I?
Veit einhver hvar pabbi minn er?Does anybody know where my dad is?
Does anybody know where my dad is?
Hver er hann?Who is he?
Who is he?

text: (archaic) in relations with a demonstrative pronoun (this, that, these) or personal pronoun (I, we, they), which represents the genitive of a relative pronoun.
examples: Maður er sá, er Jón heitir.There is a man who is named John.
There is a man who is named John.
Konan, er hann var að tala við.The woman to whom he was talking.
The woman to whom he was talking.
Þetta er borgin, er hann kom frá.This is the city from which he originated.
This is the city from which he originated.
Bærinn, er hún ætlar til.The town to which she's heading.
The town to which she's heading.
Það er sú bók, er menn þekkja eigi höfund hennar.There is a book whose author people don't know.
There is a book whose author people don't know.

text: (with an "indexical"; ábendingarorð) of a place, of a time
examples: En er dómarinn andaðist, breyttu þeir að nýju verr en feður þeirra, með því að elta aðra guði til þess að þjóna þeim og falla fram fyrir þeim. Þeir létu eigi af gjörðum sínum né þrjóskubreytni sinni.But when the judge died, the people returned to ways even more corrupt than those of their ancestors, following other gods and serving and worshiping them. They refused to give up their evil practices and stubborn ways.

But when the judge died, the people returned to ways even more corrupt than those of their ancestors, following other gods and serving and worshiping them. They refused to give up their evil practices and stubborn ways.
Þar er ég kom.There whence I came.
There whence I came.
Þá er myndin var búin.When the movie was finished.
When the movie was finished.

text: The twelfth letter of the Icelandic alphabet, written in the Latin script.

defs.etymology: From Old Norse í, from Proto-Germanic *in, from Proto-Indo-European *h₁én.

text: (with accusative) for; over (spanning a time period)
examples: Ég geng í kirkjuna. ― I walk to the church
Hann er í húsinu. ― He is in the house
Við ókum í tvær klukkustundir. ― We drove for two hours.

defs.etymology: From Old Norse ekki (“nothing”), from eitt (neuter of einn (“one”)) + negative suffix -gi, -ki.

examples: Ég er ekki Alda!I'm not Alda!
I'm not Alda!
Ég fer ekki í dag því ég fann ekki vegabréfið mitt.I'm not leaving today because I didn't find my passport.
I'm not leaving today because I didn't find my passport.
Ekki fara!Don't go!
Don't go!

defs.etymology: From Old Norse ekki, from Proto-Germanic *inkô.

text: ekki m (genitive singular ekka, nominative plural ekkar)

defs.etymology: From Old Norse ok.

examples: Kona og maður.A woman and a man.
A woman and a man.
Ég heiti Baldur og þetta er Jón.My name is Baldur and this is Jón.
My name is Baldur and this is Jón.

text: The second letter of the Icelandic alphabet, written in the Latin script.
The name of the Latin-script letter Á.

defs.etymology: From Old Norse á (“river”), from Proto-Germanic *ahwō, from Proto-Indo-European *h₂ekʷeh₂ (“water”). Compare Danish å, Norwegian å, Swedish å.

text: á f (genitive singular ár, nominative plural ár)
examples: Synonym: fljót, elfur, elfa

defs.etymology: Inflection of á.
Inflection of ær.
Conjugation of eiga.

text: first-person singular present indicative of eiga I own.
third-person singular present indicative of eiga He owns.

defs.etymology: (This etymology is missing or incomplete. Please add to it, or discuss it at the Etymology scriptorium. Particularly: “perhaps onomatopoeic?”)

examples: Á! Þetta var vont!Ouch! That hurt!
Ouch! That hurt!
Synonyms: ái, áts, æ

defs.etymology: From Old Norse á, from Proto-Norse ᚨᚾ (an), from Proto-Germanic *ana.

examples: Hvar eru lyklarnir? - Þeir eru á borðinu.Where are the keys? - They are on the table.
Where are the keys? - They are on the table.
Ég bý á Íslandi.I live in Iceland.
I live in Iceland.
Hvað heitir þetta á íslensku?What’s this called in Icelandic?
What’s this called in Icelandic?

defs.etymology: From Old Norse hann, from Proto-Norse *hānaʀ (*hānaʀ), of uncertain origin.

text: (personal pronoun): accusative singular form of the word hann (meaning "he") meaning "him".
examples: Hann er gamall.He is old.
He is old.
Hann drap hann.He killed him.
He killed him.
Hann drap hann.He killed him.
He killed him.
Hættu þessu! Ég elska hann!Stop it! I love him!
Stop it! I love him!

defs.etymology: From Old Norse sem (“as, like”), possibly from Proto-Germanic *samaz (“same, alike”).

text: (relative, with a clause) who, which, that
examples: Hann var sem guð meðal manna.He was like a god amongst men.
He was like a god amongst men.
Hár hennar var hvítt sem snjór.Her hair was white as snow.
Her hair was white as snow.
Hann er sem nýr.He is as [good as] new.
He is as [good as] new.
Vista sem…Save as…
Save as…
Svo virðist sem sjúkdómurinn sé arfgengurIs seems as though the disease is hereditary.
Is seems as though the disease is hereditary.
Þetta er maðurinn sem ég hitti í gær.That’s the man that I met yesterday.
That’s the man that I met yesterday.
Þetta er konan sem barði mig.That’s the woman who hit me.
That’s the woman who hit me.

text: first-person singular present indicative of semja

ipa.kind: before words beginning with a consonant

examples: Frá mér til þín.From me to you.
From me to you.

defs.etymology: From Old Norse til, from Proto-Germanic *tila- (“goal”), from Proto-Indo-European *ád (“near, at”).

examples: Ég fer til Japans.I'm going to Japan.
I'm going to Japan.
Ég er með bréf til þín.I have a letter [addressed] to you.
I have a letter [addressed] to you.
Nei, Elín? En gaman að sjá þig! ― Elín? How good to see you!

text: than (with an adjective in the comparative)
(formal written language) used to join closely linked sentences, similar to a semicolon in English
examples: Ég drekk kaffi en ég drekk ekki te. ― I drink coffee but I don't drink tea.
Ég ætla að fá brauð en ekki mjólk. ― I'll have bread but not milk.
Ég er betri en bróðir minn. ― I'm better than my brother.
Hún er skemmtilegri en ég. ― She is more fun than I am.
Rannsókn embættis sérstaks saksóknara á meintum innherjasvikum Baldurs Guðlaugssonar stóð yfir í rúmlega ár, en FME kærði málið með bréfi til embættisins hinn 9. júlí á síðasta ári.
Sonur hans hét Jón, en dóttir hans Ása. ― His son was named John and his daughter was named Ása.
Veðrið var ekki gott framan af: rigning á fjallinu, en þoka í byggð. ― The weather was not good to begin with: rain in the mountains, and fog in the countryside.

defs.etymology: From Old Norse fyrir (“before, for”), from Proto-Germanic *furi (“before, for”).

examples: Þetta er ekki fyrir börn. ― This is not for children.
Synonyms: handa, til

defs.etymology: From Old Norse af, from Proto-Germanic *ab.
From Old Norse um, from Proto-Germanic *umbi (“around, about”).

examples: Það er um að gera að sofa vel.The important thing to do is to sleep well.
The important thing to do is to sleep well.
Hvað er um að vera?What's going on?
What's going on?
Eins og um var talað.As was agreed.
As was agreed.
Um hvað ertu að tala?What are you talking about?
What are you talking about?
Spurning um líf og dauða.A question of life and death.
A question of life and death.
Áin rennur um dalinn.The river runs through the valley.
The river runs through the valley.
Að fara út um gluggann.To go out through the window.
To go out through the window.
Vestur um haf.West across the sea.
West across the sea.
Við förum um alla sveitina.We'll go throughout the district.
We'll go throughout the district.
Hann var breiður um herðar.He was broad across the shoulders.
He was broad across the shoulders.
Hún hafði klút um hálsinn.She had a scarf around her neck.
She had a scarf around her neck.
Hvenær gerðist þetta? - Þetta gerðist um sumarið.When did this happen? - It happened during the summer.
When did this happen? - It happened during the summer.
Ég fór um nóttina.I went during the night.
I went during the night.
Pokinn er um fjögur kíló.The bag is around four kilos.
The bag is around four kilos.

defs.etymology: From Old Norse varr, from Proto-Germanic *waraz.

text: var n (genitive singular vars, nominative plural vör)

defs.etymology: Inflected form of vera (“to be”).

text: first/third-person singular past indicative of vera

defs.etymology: From Old Norse mik.

examples: Þú drapst mig.You killed me.
You killed me.
Ég brenndi mig.I burnt myself.
I burnt myself.

defs.etymology: From Old Norse at (“that”). From Proto-Germanic *þat (“that”). Cognate with Old English þæt, Gothic 𐌸𐌰𐍄𐌰 (þata).

examples: Hún sagði mér að þessi bók væri góð lesning.She told me that this book was a good read.
She told me that this book was a good read.

defs.etymology: From Old Norse at (“at, to”), from Proto-Germanic *at (“at, to”). More at at.

examples: Göngum að húsinu.Let's walk towards the house.
Let's walk towards the house.

defs.etymology: From Old Norse já (“yes”), Proto-Germanic *ja (“yes”).

text: (informal) yes (as an exclamation of joy or excitement)

defs.etymology: From Old Norse hón.
From Old Norse nei, from Proto-Germanic *nai (“never”), *nē (“not”), from Proto-Indo-European *ne, *nē, *nēy (negative particle).

words: (no): já, júts (children's slang), jú (implies a positive contradiction, used to contradict a negative)

defs.etymology: From Old Norse *bara (“barely, only”), from *barr, Old West Norse berr, from Proto-Germanic *bazaz (“bare”). Compare Swedish bara.

examples: Ég á bara 200 krónur.I only have 200 krónur.
I only have 200 krónur.
Bara að hann hringi í mig...If only he'd call me...
If only he'd call me...
Þegiðu bara!Just shut up!
Just shut up!
Gerðu þetta bara og þegiðu!Just do it and shut up.
Just do it and shut up.

defs.etymology: From Old Norse svá, from Proto-Germanic *swa, *swē, from Proto-Indo-European *swe and Proto-Indo-European *se. Cognate with Old English swā (English so), Old Frisian sa, Old Saxon sō, Dutch zo, Old High German sō (German so), Swedish så, Danish så, Gothic 𐍃𐍅𐌰 (swa), Latin si (from an earlier form suad), Oscan 𐌔𐌅𐌀𐌝 (svaí), Umbrian sve, Greek ὡς (hōs) (earlier *ϝως).

examples:
Svo.. Hvenær eigum við að koma til ykkar?
So.. When shall we come over?
So.. When shall we come over?

text: third-person plural present of vera (“to be”): they are
examples: Menn eru illir.Men are evil.
Men are evil.

defs.etymology: From Old Norse ef, from Proto-Germanic *jabai.

text: you are, second-person of vera (meaning "to be")
examples: Þú ert skemmtileg.You are fun.
You are fun.
Hver ert þú?Who are you?
Who are you?

defs.etymology: From Old Norse þat (“it, that”), from Proto-Germanic *þat, from Proto-Indo-European *tód (neuter of *só). Cognates include Swedish det, Faroese tað and English that.

examples: Það gerðist fyrir nokkrum árum. ― It happened several years ago.
Það er lítið rautt hús á horninu. ― There is a little red house on the corner.
Hann vildi ekki borða það. ― He didn't want to eat that.
Ég vissi ekki að hann væri það veikur. ― I didn't know he was that ill.

defs.etymology: From ert (“[you] are”) + þú (“you”).

examples: Ég ætla að lesa eins hratt og ég get. ― I'm going to read as fast as I can.
Ég hef aldrei keyrt eins mikið. ― I have never driven that much.
Are you really going to kill us all?
This package is from all of us?

defs.etymology: From Old Norse vera, earlier vesa, from Proto-Germanic *wesaną. Cognate with Danish være, Norwegian Bokmål være, Norwegian Nynorsk vera, and Swedish vara.

text: vera (strong verb, third-person singular past indicative var, third-person plural past indicative voru, supine verið)
(transitive, intransitive, takes nominative adjectives or nouns) to be
examples: Það er gaman að vera góður.It is fun being good.
It is fun being good.
Að vera eða vera ekki.To be or not to be.
To be or not to be.
Ég var kennari áður en ég gerðist stærðfræðingur.I was a teacher before I become a mathematician.
I was a teacher before I become a mathematician.
Hvernig veistu að þetta sé ekki gildra?How do you know that this is not a trap?
How do you know that this is not a trap?

text: vera f (genitive singular veru, nominative plural verur)

defs.etymology: From Old Norse eptir, eptr, from Proto-Germanic *aftiri (“more aft, further behind”), *after, from Proto-Indo-European *apotero (“further behind, further away”), comparative form of *apo- (“off, behind”).

text: after, in (temporal; e.g., after three days)
examples: Ég kem eftir tíu mínútur.I'll be there in ten minutes.
I'll be there in ten minutes.

defs.etymology: From Old Norse gera, gøra, gørva, from Proto-Germanic *garwijaną.

text: gera (weak verb, third-person singular past indicative gerði, supine gert)
(impersonal) used with nouns denoting a weather condition to indicate that that type of weather is going on
examples: Hvað ertu að gera?What are you doing?
What are you doing?
Letingjar gera aldrei neitt.Loafers never do anything.
Loafers never do anything.
Það gerði rigningu.It rained.
It rained.

text: first/third-person singular active present indicative of vita
second-person singular active present indicative of hafa
third-person singular active present indicative of hafa

defs.etymology: From Old Norse hér (“here”), from Proto-Germanic *hē₂r.

examples: Ríðum, ríðum og rekum yfir sandinn,
rennur sól á bak við Arnarfell,
hér á reiki er margur óhreinn andinn,
úr því fer að skyggja á jökulsvell;
Drottinn leiði drösulinn minn,

drjúgur verður síðasti áfanginn.
Ride, ride, ride hard across the sands,the sun is settling behind Arnarfell.Here many spirits of the darkthreaten in the gloom over the glacier's ice.The Lord leads my horse,it is still a long, long way home.
Ride, ride, ride hard across the sands,
the sun is settling behind Arnarfell.
Here many spirits of the dark
threaten in the gloom over the glacier's ice.
The Lord leads my horse,
it is still a long, long way home.

defs.etymology: From Old Norse nú, from Proto-Germanic *nu (“now”), from Proto-Indo-European *nū (“now”).

examples: Nú drekkum við velkomandaminni!Now we drink to his/her arrival!
Now we drink to his/her arrival!
Krummi krunkar úti,
kallar á nafna sinn:
„Ég fann höfud af hrúti
hrygg og gæruskinn.“
Komdu nú og kroppaðu með mér,
krummi nafni minn.“Krummi croaks outside,calling his namesake:‘I found the head of a ram,backbone and sheepskin.’Come now and peck with me,Krummi, my namesake.”
“Krummi croaks outside,
calling his namesake:
‘I found the head of a ram,
backbone and sheepskin.’
Come now and peck with me,
Krummi, my namesake.”

defs.etymology: From Old Norse frá, from Proto-Germanic *fram.

text: adverbial form of preposition, used in compounds

defs.etymology: From Old Norse fara, from Proto-Germanic *faraną, from Proto-Indo-European *por- (“going, passage”).

text: fara (strong verb, third-person singular past indicative fór, third-person plural past indicative fóru, supine farið)
examples: Ég fór út í búð og keypti brauð.I went to the store and bought bread.
I went to the store and bought bread.
Ég er að fara.I am leaving.
I am leaving.

defs.etymology: From Old Norse þú, from Proto-Germanic *þū, from Proto-Indo-European *túh₂. Cognate with English thou, German du.

examples: Þú ert skemmtilegur.You are fun.
You are fun.
Ertu nemandi?Are you a student?
Are you a student?

defs.etymology: From Old Norse hvernig.

text: how ("in what manner" or "in what state"; "to what degree" is hve or hversu)

defs.etymology: From Old Norse vit, the first-person dual personal pronoun; the plural was vér.

text: (personal pronoun) we, nominative plural form of the personal pronoun ég (“I”)
examples: Við erum vinir. ― We are friends.

defs.etymology: From Old Norse við.

text: (with accusative, idiomatic, between people) with, to
examples: Ég stend við vegginn. ― I'm standing next to the wall.

defs.etymology: From Old Norse út, from Proto-Germanic *ūt.
From Old Norse upp, from Proto-Germanic *upp.
From Old Norse aptr, from Proto-Germanic *aftrą.
From Old Norse svána. Composed of svo (“so, thus”) +‎ -na (proximal suffix).

words: (to this degree): svo (“so, to such a degree”), það (“to that degree”)

examples: Til þess að hitta í körfuna verðurðu að kasta boltanum svona.To hit the basket you have to throw the ball like this.
To hit the basket you have to throw the ball like this.
Ég vissi ekki að þú værir svona góður!I didn’t know you were this good!
I didn’t know you were this good!
Ég fór síðast í bíó fyrir svona mánuði.The last time I went to the movies was like a month ago.
The last time I went to the movies was like a month ago.

words: (like this): slíkur (“such, like that”), þannig (“like that”), svoleiðis (“like that”)

examples: Það er eitthvað að svona fólki.There’s something wrong with people like this.
There’s something wrong with people like this.

defs.etymology: From Old Norse mínn, from Proto-Germanic *mīnaz, from Proto-Indo-European *méynos.

text: (possessive) my, mine (used referring to someone/something masculine)
examples: Krummi krunkar úti,
kallar á nafna sinn:
„Ég fann höfud af hrúti
hrygg og gæruskinn.“
Komdu nú og kroppaðu með mér,
krummi nafni minn.“Krummi croaks outside,calling his namesake:‘I found the head of a ram,backbone and sheepskin.’Come now and peck with me,Krummi, my namesake.”
“Krummi croaks outside,
calling his namesake:
‘I found the head of a ram,
backbone and sheepskin.’
Come now and peck with me,
Krummi, my namesake.”
Ríðum, ríðum og rekum yfir sandinn,
rennur sól á bak við Arnarfell,
hér á reiki er margur óhreinn andinn,
úr því fer að skyggja á jökulsvell;
Drottinn leiði drösulinn minn,

drjúgur verður síðasti áfanginn.
Ride, ride, ride hard across the sands,the sun is settling behind Arnarfell.Here many spirits of the darkthreaten in the gloom over the glacier's ice.The Lord leads my horse,it is still a long, long way home.
Ride, ride, ride hard across the sands,
the sun is settling behind Arnarfell.
Here many spirits of the dark
threaten in the gloom over the glacier's ice.
The Lord leads my horse,
it is still a long, long way home.
Þetta er maðurinn minn, hann Þorlákur.This is my husband Þorlákur.
This is my husband Þorlákur.

defs.etymology: From Old Norse vel, from Proto-Germanic *wela.

text: vel (comparative betur, superlative best) (háttaratviksorð (“adverb of manner”))
first-person singular present indicative of sjá
first-person singular present subjunctive of vera
third-person singular present subjunctive of vera

examples: Hún kyssir hana.She kisses her.
She kisses her.

defs.etymology: Possibly derived from þarna or hérna.

text: "there!" (said when handing an item to someone or to indicate that something is finished or ready)

defs.etymology: From Old Norse hverr, from Proto-Germanic *hweraz.

text: hver m (genitive singular hvers, nominative plural hverir or hverar)

defs.etymology: From Old Norse hverr (from Proto-Germanic *hwarjaz) and *hver (from Proto-Germanic *hwaz), which were conflated in (late) Old Norse. Most of the inflected forms of *hwaz have since become obsolete, and what remains in form is essentially the descendant of *hwarjaz, but with an extra form for the neuter nominative and accusative singular: hvað from Old Norse hvat.

text: hver (feminine hver, neuter hvert or hvað)
(interrogative) which (referring to one or several of more than two things or persons; may be qualified by a noun phrase in genitive or a noun phrase with the preposition af (“of”))
(interrogative, neuter singular) what, which part (referring to part of a mass or group of things or people considered collectively; may be qualified by a noun phrase with the preposition af (“of”))
(relative) whichever (of more than two things or persons; followed by a relative clause; may be qualified by a noun phrase in genitive or a noun phrase with the preposition af (“of”))
(relative, neuter singular) whatever (followed by a relative clause; may be qualified by a noun phrase with the preposition af (“of”))
(relative, chiefly archaic) who, which, that (used in the forming of relative clauses)
examples: Hver er ég?Who am I?
Who am I?
Hver stal kökunni úr krúsinni í gær?Who stole the cookie from the jar last night?
Who stole the cookie from the jar last night?
Hver þeirra finnst þér bestur, hvíti, græni eða appelsínuguli bíllinn?Which of these do you like best, the white, the green, or the orange car?
Which of these do you like best, the white, the green, or the orange car?
Við verðum að ákveða hvað af landinu við viljum vernda fyrir snjóflóð.We have to decide which part of the land we want to protect from avalanches.
We have to decide which part of the land we want to protect from avalanches.
Hver sem ég talaði við í dag var í góðu skapi.Whoever I talked to today was in a good mood.
Whoever I talked to today was in a good mood.
Hvað sem ég reyndi, það tókst ekki.Whatever I tried, it didn't work.
Whatever I tried, it didn't work.
Besta rúgbrauðið kemur frá Hveragerði. Það veit hver íslendingur.The best ‘rye bread’ is from Hveragerði. Every Icelander knows that.
The best ‘rye bread’ is from Hveragerði. Every Icelander knows that.

Hver maður er borinn frjáls og jafn öðrum að virðingu og réttindum. Menn eru gæddir vitsmunum og samvizku, og ber þeim að breyta bróðurlega hverjum við annan.All human beings are born free and equal in dignity and rights. They are endowed with reason and conscience and should act towards one another in a spirit of brotherhood.
All human beings are born free and equal in dignity and rights. They are endowed with reason and conscience and should act towards one another in a spirit of brotherhood.
God loves you!
Nobody wants to give you presents.

defs.etymology: From Old Norse segja, from Proto-Germanic *sagjaną, ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *sekʷ-.

text: segja (weak verb, third-person singular past indicative sagði, supine sagt)
(transitive, governs the dative) to say, to tell
examples: Heyr, einhver segir: "Kalla þú!" Og ég svara: "Hvað skal ég kalla?" "Allt hold er gras og allur yndisleikur þess sem blóm vallarins. Grasið visnar, blómin fölna, þegar Drottinn andar á þau. Sannlega, mennirnir eru gras. Grasið visnar, blómin fölna, en orð Guðs vors stendur stöðugt eilíflega."A voice says, "Cry out." And I said, "What shall I cry?" "All men are like grass, and all their glory is like the flowers of the field. The grass withers and the flowers fall, because the breath of the LORD blows on them. Surely the people are grass. The grass withers and the flowers fall, but the word of our God stands forever."

A voice says, "Cry out." And I said, "What shall I cry?" "All men are like grass, and all their glory is like the flowers of the field. The grass withers and the flowers fall, because the breath of the LORD blows on them. Surely the people are grass. The grass withers and the flowers fall, but the word of our God stands forever."
Ég segi söguna á eftir.I'll tell the story later.
I'll tell the story later.
Segðu mér eitthvað skemmtilegt.Tell me something interesting.
Tell me something interesting.

text: [we] are, the first person plural of vera (meaning "to be")
examples: Við erum meistararnir!We are the champions!
We are the champions!
Hvar ertu? — Ég er hérna.Where are you? — I'm here.
Where are you? — I'm here.

text: úr n (genitive singular úrs, nominative plural úr)

defs.etymology: From Old Norse ór (“out of”), from Proto-Germanic *uz (“out, out of”). More at or-.

examples: Hver stal kökunni úr krúsinni í gær?Who stole the cookie from the jar  last night?
Who stole the cookie from the jar  last night?
Ég mun aldrei fyrirgefa þér.I will never forgive you.
I will never forgive you.
Hún sagðist að hún myndi koma til klukkan 8 en hún kemur aldrei á réttum tíma.She said she'd show up at 8, but she never shows up on time.
She said she'd show up at 8, but she never shows up on time.

text: (strong positive degree neuter nominative form of góður; meaning good
(strong positive degree neuter accusative form of góður; meaning good
examples: Guð sagði: „Verði ljós!“ Og það varð ljós. Guð sá, að ljósið var gott, og Guð greindi ljósið frá myrkrinu. Og Guð kallaði ljósið dag, en myrkrið kallaði hann nótt. Það varð kveld og það varð morgunn, hinn fyrsti dagur.And God said, "Let there be light," and there was light. God saw that the light was good, and He separated the light from the darkness. God called the light "day," and the darkness he called "night." And there was evening, and there was morning—the first day.

And God said, "Let there be light," and there was light. God saw that the light was good, and He separated the light from the darkness. God called the light "day," and the darkness he called "night." And there was evening, and there was morning—the first day.

defs.etymology: From Old Norse hvar, from Proto-Germanic *hwar.

examples: Hvar áttu heima? ― Where do you live?
Hvar er hann niðurkominn? ― What’s become of him?
Hvar í ósköpunum varstu, Óskar? ― Where in heaven’s name were you, Óskar?

defs.etymology: From Old Norse hafa, from Proto-Germanic *habjaną, from Proto-Indo-European *keh₂p- (“take, seize”).

text: hafa (weak verb, third-person singular past indicative hafði, supine haft)
(transitive, governs the accusative) to hold, to have
examples: Ég hef ekki tíma í kvöldmat.I don't have time for dinner.
I don't have time for dinner.
María hefur áhuga á stjórnmálum.Maria is interested in politics.
Maria is interested in politics.
Hvernig hefurðu það? - Ég hef það fínt.How are you doing? - I'm fine.
How are you doing? - I'm fine.

defs.etymology: See haf.
Inherited from Old Norse hjá.

text: (with dative) by, near, next to, at (someone’s) place

defs.etymology: From Old Norse koma, from Proto-Germanic *kwemaną, from Proto-Indo-European *gʷem-.

text: koma (strong verb, third-person singular past indicative kom, third-person plural past indicative komu, supine komið)
examples: Krummi krunkar úti,
kallar á nafna sinn:
„Ég fann höfud af hrúti
hrygg og gæruskinn.“
Komdu nú og kroppaðu með mér,
krummi nafni minn.“Krummi croaks outside,calling his namesake:‘I found the head of a ram,backbone and sheepskin.’Come now and peck with me,Krummi, my namesake.”
“Krummi croaks outside,
calling his namesake:
‘I found the head of a ram,
backbone and sheepskin.’
Come now and peck with me,
Krummi, my namesake.”

defs.etymology: From Old Norse kváma; from the root of the verb koma.

text: koma f (genitive singular komu, nominative plural komur)

examples: That letter was for us.
Hvenær komumst við inn?When can we get inside?
When can we get inside?

defs.etymology: From Old Norse fá, from Proto-Germanic *fanhaną. Doublet of fanga (“to capture, to seize”).

text: fá (strong verb, third-person singular past indicative fékk, third-person plural past indicative fengu, supine fengið)
(transitive, with accusative) to receive, to get
(ditransitive, with dative and accusative objects) to give (somebody something)

defs.etymology: (This etymology is missing or incomplete. Please add to it, or discuss it at the Etymology scriptorium.)

Borrowed from Danish tak, from Old Norse þǫkk (whence inherited Icelandic þökk), from Proto-Germanic *þankō, *þankaz. Cognates include Faroese and Norwegian takk, Danish tak, Swedish tack, English thank, West Frisian tank, Dutch dank and German Dank.

text: please: used to make a polite request.

words: þakka þér (singular); þakka yður (singular, formal; rare)
þakka þér fyrir (singular); þakka yður fyrir (singular, formal; rare)
takk kærlega (“thank you dearly; thank you very much”)
kærar þakkir (“dear thanks; thank you very much”)

examples: Einn kaffibolla, takk.One cup of coffee, please.
One cup of coffee, please.
Já, takk.Yes, please.
Yes, please.

defs.etymology: Cognates include Faroese kanska, Norwegian Nynorsk kanskje, Norwegian Bokmål kanskje, Swedish kanske

From Old Norse hvat, originally the neuter form of *hver (from Proto-Germanic *hwaz), but conflated with hverr (whence Modern Icelandic hver). Corresponds to Proto-Germanic *hwat, from Proto-Indo-European *kʷód, *kʷod. See hver.
